did.unittitle: Benjamin Franklin Papers Part 14 -- Materials held at the University of Pennsylvania
did.abstract:
This is part of the large inventory for the Benjamin Franklin Papers (Mss B F85). For complete information concerning this collection, please view the
Collection Description. The materials listed here are not held at the APS.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The materials in this collection were originally part of the collection bequeathed by Benjamin Franklin to his grandson, William Temple Franklin, and then given to George Fox. When the bulk of that collection was donated to the American Philosophical Society, some manuscripts were left behind at the Fox estate, Champlost, and these were subsequently donated to the University of Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials that comprise the University of Pennsylvania's Benjamin Franklin Papers are concentrated in the period of the American Revolution, documenting Franklin's ministry in France, the progress of the American Revolution and French participation, and Franklin's personal affairs in France.

The organization of the collection is essentially chronological, however there are three discrete chronological sequences. The item listing below is derived from I. Minis Hays's calendar of the Franklin Papers without emendation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a convey for the vessel "Marquis de la Fayette," which will soon be freighted for America. A consul much needed at Nantes, in order to enlist American seamen in the American service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolutions complimentary to John Paul Jones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his protest against freight duty charged on the cargo of the "Aurora." Has his servant [Mark Anthony] back but is under bonds to send him away in six months; complains bitterly of the Procureur's attitude in this affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accession of Maryland to the Confederation of States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing extracts from the minutes of Congress [February 27, 1781], and instructing Dr. Franklin to communicate them to the King of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On behalf of the officers and men of the "Alliance," urges the payment of the prize-money due them; the present Commander of the "Alliance," [Capt. John Barry], much liked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ship, "Marquis de la Fayette," ready to sail for America after the equinox; awaits Dr. Franklin's final orders as to her destination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Marquis de la Fayette" and the "Alliance" have just sailed; the despatches to be sent by the "Aurora."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is coming to Passy. Recently travelled with [Thomas] Paine, the author of "Common Sense"; Paine's opinion of [Silas] Deane and [Arthur] Lee. Advantage of sending cloth to America to be made up into uniforms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning an action which took place on May 2d between the French squadron and an English fleet, from St. Eustatius, of thirty-four merchant vessels, escorted by the "Vengeance" and other ships; twenty-two merchant vessels and two corsairs taken.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his appointment as Minister of Finance; undertakes the work at a great sacrifice of his domestic happiness; Dr. Franklin's support will be highly esteemed; aware that anyone in a high station must be subject to bitter attacks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Empowering Dr. Franklin to offer Lieut-Gen. [John] Burgoyne in exchange for the Honorable Henry Laurens.

(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the bearer, Major [David Salisbury] Franks, of the American Army, to Dr. Franklin's notice and friendship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Dr. Franklin to sound some of the eminent bankers in Paris, as to the credit they are willing to give to a United States bank founded upon the enclosed plan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deplorable state of the country's finances due to the use of paper money. Money needed to start a bank and a Mint. Mr. [John] Jay instructed to negotiate a large loan at Madrid. Unfair to ask France for more money. Desiring Dr. Franklin to confer with leading bankers in Paris as to organizing a National Bank in America. Advising that the money loaned by France should remain in that country. Attempts made by Congress to raise the value of paper money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends letters for Dr. Franklin which arrived on the brig "Sally," from Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchase of cannon. Capture of a cutter in the Bay of Biscay, by two American privateers. An American vessel from Port-au-Prince chased on shore by a British vessel and totally wrecked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution appointing Robert R. Livingston Secretary for Foreign Affairs.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Feels the calamities of the war and among them the discontinuance of his intercourse with Dr. Franklin; has desired his friendship for a long time. Concerning the reported application of Congress for the return of his friend, Gen. [John] Burgoyne, to captivity in America; appeals to Dr. Franklin not to suffer this injustice to take place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

A. E. urging that this request be granted. S. B[enjamin] Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a recommentation to M. de Fleury. Has tried to repay Dr. Franklin's favors by turning over business to Mr. [Richard] Bache's house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires him to send his grandson [Benjamin Franklin Bache] to a Catholic Academy in which he is interested; describes the curriculum; Protestants frequently place their children in this school.

scopecontent.p: Encloses speeches of Mr. [Charles James] Fox. The London paper honored the writer by recording that he breakfasted with Mr. [Henry] Laurens. Enclosing resolutions of the Volunteer Corps, showing their contempt for the treachery of Mr. [Francis] Dobbs.

scopecontent.p: Refers to his two former letters and begs that his petition may be answered, and if possible, granted.

scopecontent.p: Money needed for purchasing supplies for the States; a further sum will have to be drawn on France; if necessary all French advances could be repaid at the end of the year; for this he pledges his personal honor.

scopecontent.p: Two million livres will need to be drawn on France; the Dutch loan will provide in part for the payment.

scopecontent.p: Introducing William Rawle, son of the late Francis Rawle, of Philadelphia. Failure of their old friends Brown, Collinson and Tritton; hopes Dr. Franklin loses nothing thereby. The new Ministry apparently determined to proceed on true Constitutional principles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a book written by a man who saved his wife's life; he will find it full of valuable knowledge.
